key_points: California will require COVID-19 vaccinations for students to attend in-person classes, becoming the first state in the U.S. to announce such a mandate.
The requirement will be added to the list of mandatory school vaccinations, like those for measles, mumps, and rubella.
Implementation will begin following FDA full approval for each grade span: 7-12 and K-6.
Governor Gavin Newsom cited the state's previous successful health measures and the goal to protect children and school staff as reasons for this decision.
California's public health measures have led to it having the lowest case rate in the country and minimal school closures.
Over 95% of students have returned to in-person instruction this school year in California.
The COVID-19 vaccine requirements will be phased in by grade span to allow smoother implementation.
Full FDA approval for specific age groups will trigger the requirement for corresponding grade spans.
Local health jurisdictions and education agencies are encouraged to adopt these requirements ahead of the statewide mandate based on their circumstances.
Governor Newsom's education package aims to transform California public schools with significant funding and programs.
